Scheme 1 The steps for the preparation of Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst. Fig. 1 TEM image and particle size distribution of Pd nanoparticles. Fig. 2 TEM images of (a) Pd@SiO2, (b) Pd@SiO2@ZrO2, (c) Pd@void@ZrO2 and STEM image and EDX results (inset) of (d) Pd@void@ZrO2. Fig. 3 N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2. Fig. 4 XRD results of Pd-cube/SiO2 (impregnated), Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2. Fig. 5 Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide using Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst in the presence of H3PO4 and Br− ions: (a) H2 conversion and H2O2 selectivity; (b) H2O2 productivity (gram-Pd-specific H2O2 production rate). Test conditions: 293K, 1atm, 1mg of Pd, 150mL of ethanol/water (4/1, v/v) mixture (containing 0.15mM KBr and 0.03M H3PO4), stirring rate=1200rpm, total gas flow rate=22mL/min, H2/O2 =1/10 (v /v). Fig. 6 Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide using Pd@void@ZrO2 catalysts under different Br− ion concentrations and in the presence of H3PO4: (a) H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity and H2O2 yield; (b) H2O2 productivity (gram-Pd-specific H2O2 production rate). Test conditions: 293K, 1atm, 1mg of Pd, 150mL of ethanol/water (4/1, v /v) mixture (containing 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.3, 0.6, 0.9 and 1.2mM KBr and 0.03M H3PO4), stirring rate=1200rpm, total gas flow rate=22mL/min, H2/O2 =1/10 (v /v). Table 1 Pd contents, Pd surface area and BET surface area of the prepared catalysts. Catalyst Pd loading (wt.%) a Exposed Pd area (m2/g-Pd) b Specific surface area (m2/g) c Pd@SiO2 0.9 23.7 282 Pd@void@ZrO2 0.5 36.8 347 a Pd loadings were calculated from the ICP-AES data. b Exposed Pd areas were calculated based on the CO chemisorption results. c The total specific surface area was estimated by BET method. A yolk–shell structured Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst for direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen Myung-gi Seo a 1 Seongmin Kim a 1 Ha Eun Jeong a Dae-Won Lee b ⁎ Kwan-Young Lee a c d ⁎⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea b Department of Chemical Engineering, Kangwon National University, 1 Kangwondaehak-gil, Chuncheon-si, Gangwon-do 24341, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering Kangwon National University 1 Kangwondaehak-gil Chuncheon-si Gangwon-do 24341 Republic of Korea c Green School, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea Green School Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea d KU-KIST Graduate School of Converging Science and Technology, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea KU-KIST Graduate School of Converging Science and Technology Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical Engineering, Kangwon National University, 1 Kangwondaehak-gil, Chuncheon-si, Gangwon-do 24341, Republic of Korea. Tel.: +82 33 250 6331; fax: +82 33 251 3658. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, 145, Anam-ro, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea. Tel.: +82 2 3290 3299; fax: +82 2 926 6102. 1 These authors contributed equally to the manuscript. Graphical abstract In this study, we prepared a yolk–shell structured Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst and tested its activity in direct hydrogen synthesis from hydrogen and oxygen. The catalyst was prepared by first encapsulating the nano Pd crystal with SiO2 and then, the Pd core–silica shell composite (Pd@SiO2) was encapsulated again with ZrO2 (Pd@SiO2@ZrO2). The yolk–shell structure was obtained by etching the silica layer of Pd@SiO2@ZrO2 using 0.2M KOH solution. Compared to the core–shell structured Pd@SiO2, the void space in the yolk–shell structure allowed more gases to access the core Pd surface. In reaction tests, the production rate of gram Pd-specific H2O2 with Pd@void@ZrO2 was approximately 1.2 times higher than with Pd@SiO2. It was found that the optimum level of halide ion concentration in the reaction medium was between 0.1 and 0.3mM for Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst. Keywords Palladium-zirconia Palladium nanoparticle Direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide is a versatile chemical used in various fields of chemical industry [1–4]. It is commercially synthesized via the ‘anthraquinone process’, but the process has serious drawbacks due to the heavy use of organic chemicals [5]. The most favorable alternative is direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis, where hydrogen peroxide is obtained via catalytic oxidation of hydrogen with molecular oxygen [6]. However, its commercialization has not been realized yet, mainly because the reaction competes with side reactions that produce water. The reaction is usually performed in a 3-phase reactor where H2 and O2 gases are reacted on solid catalysts dispersed over liquid water (or an alcohol–water mixture). A mineral acid and/or halide ion salt are added to the reactor to promote H2O2 selectivity [7–10]. For the catalyst, Pd (or a Pd alloy) is used most frequently. It is crucial for the Pd species to be nano-sized crystals that have a specific morphology (crystallinity). For example, a Pd octahedron crystal that is surrounded by {111} facets is more effective at obtaining H2O2 than a Pd cube surrounded by {100} facets [11,12]. This difference is related to how actively the OO bond dissociation leading to production of water is promoted on a particular morphological facet of a nano Pd crystal [12,13]. In our previous study [14,15], we immobilized nano Pd crystals inside silica by applying the Stöber method, and the resulting core–shell Pd-SiO2 (Pd@SiO2) structure was very effective at stabilizing the Pd nanocrystals and protecting them from thermal agglomeration. The pores within the silica shell, which are required for H2 and O2 molecules to access the Pd core, were formed by incinerating organic templates used for the preparation of Pd-distributed siliceous hydrogels. The core–shell Pd@SiO2 catalyst was almost two times more active in direct H2O2 synthesis than a conventional impregnated Pd/SiO2 catalyst [15]. It showed how important the stabilization of nano Pd crystals is for obtaining high H2O2 synthesis activity from an immobilized Pd catalyst. However, the core–shell structure is limited in the use of Pd metal because a part of the Pd crystal surface is blocked by the silica shell, which restricts the access of gas molecules to the Pd surface. Such a limitation can be overcome by the core-‘hollow shell’ (yolk–shell) structure, in which nanocrystals are encapsulated by a hollow shell of oxides [16–21]. In this structure, the core metal can be accessed by more gas reactants due to the void space between core metal and shell oxide. That is, a yolk/shell structure can be used to immobilize nano metal crystals while maximizing the exposure of metal surface to the reactant gases. Therefore, we have extended previous studies about immobilization techniques of Pd nanocrystals to prepare a direct H2O2 synthesis catalyst. In this study, a yolk–shell structured Pd-ZrO2 catalyst was prepared and for the first time, its catalytic activity was measured in direct H2O2 synthesis. The yolk–shell catalyst was compared with core–shell Pd@SiO2 in terms of the degree of exposure of core Pd surface and direct H2O2 synthesis activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Pd@SiO2 Pd nanocrystals were prepared by reducing Na2PdCl4 (98%, 35.3–37.1% Pd basis, Aldrich) with l-ascorbic acid (+99%, Sigma–Aldrich) in aqueous solution, to which polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, K-value 28–34, 55,000g/mol, Sigma–Aldrich) and KBr (+99%, Sigma–Aldrich) were added as the stabilizer and the capping agent, respectively. The detailed procedure was described in our previous paper [13]. The slurry was washed with acetone under centrifugation. The PVP-stabilized Pd slurry was dispersed in 200mL of ethanol, to which 10mL of NH4OH (28–33% NH3 basis, Sigma–Aldrich), 18mL of DI water and 15mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%, Sigma–Aldrich) were added. The formation of the siliceous gel and its aging were continued by stirring at room temperature for 24h. The Pd@SiO2 was collected by centrifuging at 10,000rpm for 15min and washing with water several times. 2.2 Synthesis of Pd@void@ZrO2 As described in Scheme 1 , the synthesis of Pd@void@ZrO2 occurred in three steps: (1) Pd@SiO2 was prepared (with the procedure described in the Section 2.1); (2) Pd@SiO2 was encapsulated with ZrO2 to prepare Pd@SiO2@ZrO2 (with the procedure described in the Ref. [22]); and (3) the silica layer was etched from Pd@SiO2@ZrO2 with KOH solution. The as-prepared Pd@SiO2 particles (4.2g) were dispersed in a mixture of Lutensol AO5 (oxo alcohol ethoxylate, BASF, 0.06mL), water (1.48mL) and ethanol (400mL) with sonication. A stoichiometric amount of zirconium butoxide solution (80wt% in 1-butanol, Aldrich) was added and the solution was stirred for 15h at room temperature. The solids (Pd@SiO2@ZrO2) were collected by centrifuging at 8,000rpm for 20min and then washed with water several times. It was followed by drying at 333K overnight and calcination at 773K for 6h, both of which were performed in air. The prepared Pd@SiO2@ZrO2 was added to 500mL of KOH solution (0.2M), which was stirred for 1h to remove the inner layer of silica. The solids (Pd@void@ZrO2) were separated by centrifugation (8000rpm, 20min) and washed with water several times. Pd@void@ZrO2 was dried overnight at 333K (in air) and then reduced at 423K for 2h in a 10vol% H2/N2 gas (50mL/min). 2.3 Synthesis of Pd-cube/SiO2 (impregnated) catalyst Pd cube nanoparticles were dispersed over DI water. The Pd slurry was impregnated on SiO2 and vacuum dried at 60°C overnight. The weight-percent of Pd was approximately 0.65wt.%. The detailed procedure was identical to the one described in our previous paper [12]. 2.4 Catalyst characterization Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a Tecnai G2 F30 instrument (FEI Company, OR, USA) operated at 300kV. TEM was performed at the Seoul Center of the Korean Basic Science Institute (KBSI). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption and BET analysis were performed using a BELSORP-max instrument (BEL Japan Inc., Osaka, Japan). Before the measurements, the sample was pretreated at 423K under 10Pa for 12h. The measurements were performed at 77K. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using a D/MAX-2500/PC (Rigaku). Cu-Kα1 irradiation (λ =1.5406Å) was used as an X-ray source, and the scanning rate was 1°/min. The Pd wt% of the prepared catalysts was estimated by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) using a Polyscan 61E (Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). The Pd surface area of catalysts was determined using the CO chemisorption method. Measurements were performed at 308K on an ASAP 2020 chemisorption analyzer (Micrometrics Inc., Norcross, GA, USA). 2.5 Reaction test The reaction tests were performed in a magnetically stirred (1200rpm) double jacket glass reactor. The amount of catalyst was adjusted by fixing the total Pd metal content at 1mg. A 150mL of ethanol–water mixture (20vol% ethanol, 0–1.2mM KBr, and 0.03M H3PO4) was used as the reaction medium. The gas reactants were composed of H2 and O2 (1:10) and fed into the reactor at a total flow rate of 22mL/min. The reaction tests were carried out at 293K and atmospheric pressure for 3h. The H2O2 concentration was measured by iodometric titration, and the H2 composition in the gas flow was measured with a gas chromatograph (Younglin, ACME6000) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a Carbosieve SΙΙ-packed column. H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity, and the gram Pd-specific H2O2 production rate were calculated using Eqs. (1) –(3), respectively. (1) H 2 conversion ( % ) = moles of H 2 reacted moles of H 2 supplied × 100 (2) H 2 O 2 selectivity ( % ) = moles of H 2 O 2 formed moles of H 2 reacted × 100 (3) H 2 O 2 production rate ( m m o l / g − P d ⋅ h ) = mmoles of H 2 O 2 formed weight of Pd ( g ) in catalyst × reaction time ( h ) 3 Results and Discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Fig. 1 presents a TEM image and the size distribution of the prepared Pd nanoparticles. The morphological results were similar to those obtained in our previous study [13]. The particles were nanocubes that were 9.7nm and 1.1 in average size and aspect ratio, respectively. The TEM images of Pd@SiO2, Pd@SiO2@ZrO2, and Pd@void@ZrO2 are presented in Fig. 2 (a), (b) and (c), respectively. Fig. 2(d) shows the STEM and EDX analysis results of Pd@void@ZrO2, which confirmed the formation of the yolk–shell structure in a manner similar to that found in the literature [21].N2 adsorption–desorption analysis results of Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2 are presented in Fig. 3 and Table 1 . The adsorption isotherm of Pd@void@ZrO2 (Fig. 3) shows an enhanced hysteresis loop, which might be due to the presence of void space inside the yolk–shell structure. As a result, the specific surface area of Pd@void@ZrO2 (347m2/g) was much larger than that of Pd@SiO2 (282m2/g). Fig. 4 presents the XRD results of the prepared catalysts. The results clearly show the diffraction pattern of metallic Pd (PDF: 46-1043). No other Pd-related species were observed. The broad peaks from 10 to 40° were attributed to the shell oxides (SiO2 and ZrO2) of the catalysts. The The Pd-cube/SiO2 (impregnated) catalyst had a relatively high population of {200} phase as compared with Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2 catalysts, implying it is possible the Pd particles of Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2 changed in morphology during the preparation of catalysts. ICP-AES analysis showed that Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2 contained 0.9 and 0.5wt% of Pd, respectively (Table 1). The low Pd wt% of Pd@void@ZrO2 was probably due to the cracking of weak zirconia shells during centrifugation. The Pd particles would be separated from the cracked shells and dispersed into the water phase. It was expected that the most of these dispersed Pd particles would be lost in the course of washing following centrifugation. The gram-specific exposed Pd surface area of the catalysts was measured by CO chemisorption, and the results show that Pd@SiO2 and Pd@void@ZrO2 were 23.7 and 36.8m2/g-Pd, respectively. It was hypothesized that the formation of the void space in Pd@void@ZrO2 facilitated the access of gas molecules to the Pd surface. 3.2 Reaction results Our previous study [15] proved that the core–shell structured Pd@SiO2 was more active than conventional, impregnated Pd/SiO2 in direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis. The major reason for the high activity of Pd@SiO2 was attributed to the protection of Pd particles from thermal agglomeration during calcination by the core–shell structure. However, Fig. 5 shows that Pd@void@ZrO2 was more active than Pd@SiO2 in all of the activity indices (H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity/yield, and gram Pd-specific H2O2 production rate). The loading amount of catalyst was not based on the entire catalyst weight but on the total mass of Pd in a catalyst (1mg). Thus, the total exposed area of Pd@void@ZrO2 was higher than that of Pd@SiO2. Additionally, it has been demonstrated that ZrO2 is more desirable than SiO2 as a support material for Pd-supported catalysts because H2O2 selectivity was more enhanced by the use of a ZrO2 support [9]. Thus, the enhancements in exposed Pd area, gas transfer (through the void) and shell oxide effects might be the reasons for the enhanced activity of Pd@void@ZrO2 catalysts. Fig. 6 shows the influence of KBr concentration on the activity of Pd@void@ZrO2 catalysts. It was found that H2O2 selectivity and production rate were low without addition of KBr. Halide ions are added to the reaction medium to increase the H2O2 selectivity of Pd catalysts in direct hydrogen peroxide synthesis [7–9]. Fig. 6 shows that a small dose of KBr sharply increased H2O2 selectivity and production rate. However, when the dose of KBr increased to more than 0.15mM, all of the activity indices decreased almost proportionally to the KBr concentration. It is well known that halide ions (e.g., Br−) adsorb preferentially on the energetic edges/corners of Pd where dissociative chemisorption of the OO bonds in O2 and H2O2 is promoted [13,23]. The promotion of OO bond dissociation usually results in the production of water, thereby decreasing H2O2 selectivity and yield. On the other hand, the non-dissociative chemisorption of OO bonds occurs on the terrace Pd sites, and most of the H2O2 production progresses from there [7,24]. A proper level of Br− addition effectively deactivates the water-producing, edge/corner Pd active sites and increases H2O2 formation activity [7–9], but an excess dose of Br− could poison the beneficial terrace Pd sites as well [6,7,25]. In our experiments, it was found that the optimum level of Br− concentration for Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst was between 0.1 and 0.3mM. 4 Conclusion The yolk–shell structured Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst was prepared by etching the silica layer of Pd@SiO2@ZrO2 using 0.2M KOH aqueous solution. The void space in the yolk–shell structure allowed more gas molecules to access the surface of core Pd crystals. As a result, a greater fraction of surface Pd was exposed with Pd@void@ZrO2 than with Pd@SiO2 (36.8 and 23.7m2/g-Pd, respectively). In the activity test, all of the activity indices were higher with Pd@void@ZrO2 than with Pd@SiO2, which is likely due to the enhancements in exposed Pd area, gas transfer and shell oxide effects. The H2O2 synthesis activity of Pd@void@ZrO2 was greatly influenced by the halide ion (Br−) concentration in the reaction medium. With a Br− concentration smaller than 0.15mM, the dose of Br− ion was effective at improving H2O2 synthesis activity. However, further increases in the Br− concentration resulted in a decrease in the activity, which was expected due to the poisoning of the terrace Pd sites where H2O2 was formed. It was estimated that the optimum concentration of Br− ion was in between 0.1 and 0.3mM for the Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we prepared a yolk–shell structured Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst and tested its activity in direct hydrogen synthesis from hydrogen and oxygen. The catalyst was prepared by first encapsulating the nano Pd crystal with SiO2 and then, the Pd core–silica shell composite (Pd@SiO2) was encapsulated again with ZrO2 (Pd@SiO2@ZrO2). The yolk–shell structure was obtained by etching the silica layer of Pd@SiO2@ZrO2 using 0.2M KOH solution. Compared to the core–shell structured Pd@SiO2, the void space in the yolk–shell structure allowed more gases to access the core Pd surface. In reaction tests, the production rate of gram Pd-specific H2O2 with Pd@void@ZrO2 was approximately 1.2 times higher than with Pd@SiO2. It was found that the optimum level of halide ion concentration in the reaction medium was between 0.1 and 0.3mM for Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: A yolk–shell structured Pd@void@ZrO2 catalyst for direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from hydrogen and oxygen
